headline.main: Search for Health-Research Director Narrows to 2

docs.lead_paragraph: The field of candidates to fill the most prominent and influential post in biomedical research has been narrowed to two scientists who differ in virtually every professional particular beyond their ability to inspire zealous devotion from their advocates. The finalists under consideration to serve as director of the National Institutes of Health are Dr. Harold E. Varmus of the University of California in San Francisco, a molecular biologist who has won wide fame and a Nobel Prize for his work in analyzing the genes that cause cancer, and Dr. Judith Rodin, the provost of Yale University and a psychologist known for her research on obesity and aging, Federal officials said.

headline.main: Survey Finds Major Gains In Cutting Blood Cholesterol

docs.lead_paragraph: Blood cholesterol levels among adults dropped significantly over 12 years, and about half of all Americans now have readings in the desirable range, experts said today. Results from a new national health survey showed a 4 percent decline in the average cholesterol level, to 205 milligrams per deciliter of blood in 1990 from 213 milligrams in 1978. A level below 200 milligrams is considered desirable. The survey also found that the proportion of adults with very high blood cholesterol levels fell to 20 percent from 26 percent.
